facts.text: Appeal brought by special leave to Supreme Court challenging conviction under Section 500 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: By this appeal, which has been brought to this Court by special leave, the appellant Harbhajan Singh challenges the correctness of his conviction for an offence under S. 500 of the Indian Penal Code, and the sentence imposed on him for the said offence.

facts.text: Criminal complaint filed by Surinder Singh Kairon against Harbhajan Singh for publishing defamatory statement.

anchor.surface_text: The criminal proceedings against the appellant were started on a complaint filed by Surinder Singh Kairon, son of S. Partap Singh Kairon, who was at the relevant time the Chief Minister of the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Defamatory statement published by appellant in Blitz weekly magazine on July 23, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In his complaint, the complainant Surinder Singh alleged that the appellant had published in the Press a statement against him which was highly defamatory of him. The said statement was published in the Blitz, which is a weekly magazine of Bombay, on July 23, 1957

facts.text: Punjab Government issued Press Note on July 22/23, 1957 denying complicity of Minister's son in smuggling and challenging newspapers to name him.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on July 22/23, 1957, the Punjab Government issued a Press Note in which it was averred that certain Urdu Dailies from Jullundur were indulging in mischief and false propaganda, alleging complicity of a Ministers son in smuggling on the border.

facts.text: Appellant's impugned statement named Surinder Singh Kairon as leader of smugglers and responsible for crimes in Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: I hereby name that son of the Minister as Surinder Singh Kairon son of S. Partap Singh Kairon, Chief Minister. And I do so determined to face the consequences of the charge being openly levied by me. I further allege that the son of our Chief Minister is not only a leader of smugglers but is responsible for a large number of crimes being committed in the Punjab.

facts.text: Complaint filed in court of Magistrate First Class, Tarn Taran on August 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Then, followed the complaint which was filed by the complainant on August 17, 1957. That, shortly stated, is the background of the present criminal proceedings. The complaint was filed in the court of the Magistrate, First Class, Tarn Taran.

facts.text: Supreme Court directed transfer of case to Punjab High Court on October 4, 1957 for further transfer to Sessions Court in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant moved this Court under s. 527 of the Criminal Procedure Code for the transfer of the said case from the court of the Magistrate where it had been filed. This Court directed on October 4, 1957, that the case in question should be remitted to the Punjab High Court

facts.text: Case tried by Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the case was transferred to the court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi, and was tried by him.

facts.text: Trial court convicted appellant under Section 500 IPC and sentenced to one year simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, he convicted the appellant and sentenced him to one years simple imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant claimed protection of First and Ninth Exceptions to Section 499 IPC in trial.

anchor.surface_text: In substance, he alleged that the allegations made by him in his impugned statement were true and he had published the said allegations in the interest of public good. In other words, he claimed the protection of the First Exception to s. 499, IPC. He also pleaded that the imputation which he had made against the complainant had been made in good faith and for public good.

facts.text: Trial court allowed summoning 35 witnesses, appellant examined 20.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his defence the appellant wanted to summon 328 witnesses and a large number of documents. The trial court allowed him to summon 35 witnesses in all, but eventually he examined only 20 defence witnesses.

facts.text: Punjab High Court confirmed conviction but reduced sentence to 3 months SI and Rs. 2000 fine on November 25, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court confirmed the order of conviction passed against the appellant by the trial Judge, but ordered that instead of undergoing one years simple imprisonment, the appellant shall undergo three months simple imprisonment and pay a fine of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: High Court found publication for public good but good faith not proved.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out at this stage that the High Court found that in case the appellant had proved good faith, it would not have felt any difficulty in coming to the conclusion that the publication of the impugned statement was for the public good. But since, according to the High Court, good faith had not been proved

facts.text: Supreme Court holds impugned statement per se defamatory.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the impugned statement published by the appellant is per se defamatory. and so. we must proceed to deal with the present appeal on the basis that the said statement would harm the reputation of the complainant.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds appellant proved good faith by preponderance of probability for Ninth Exception.

anchor.surface_text: we have come to the conclusion that the High Court was in error in holding that the appellant had failed to show that he acted in good faith when he published the impugned statement.

facts.text: Publication held for public good, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case. the ingredient of public good is satisfied. and the only question which arose for decision in the court below and which arises before us. is whether the imputation can be said to have been made in good faith.

facts.text: Appellant was State Secretary of Punjab Praja Socialist Party at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was at the relevant time the State Secretary of the Punjab Praja Socialist Party. He is a public worker and belongs to an active political party.

facts.text: Ajaib Singh, SSP Amritsar, issued statement on July 25, 1957 denying Minister's son involvement in smuggling.

anchor.surface_text: After this statement was published, Mr. Ajaib Singh, Senior Superintendent of Police, Amritsar, issued a statement on the 25th July, 1957, which was published in the Tribune on the 26th July.

facts.text: Appellant filed written statement after examination under S.342 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant was examined under s. 342, Cr. P.C., he told the learned Judge that he would prefer to file a detailed written statement. Later, he did file his written statement

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside conviction allowing Ninth Exception.

anchor.surface_text: our conclusion is that the appellant is entitled to claim the protection of the Ninth Exception.

facts.text: Surinder Singh Kairon is son of Chief Minister Partap Singh Kairon.

anchor.surface_text: Surinder Singh Kairon, son of S. Partap Singh Kairon, who was at the relevant time the Chief Minister of the State of Punjab.

facts.text: High Court rejected grievance of insufficient opportunity to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: as regards the grievance made by the appellant that he had not been given a reasonable opportunity to lead his evidence, the High Court held that the said grievance was not well-founded.

facts.text: Appellant wanted to summon 328 witnesses but allowed 35.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant wanted to summon 328 witnesses and a large number of documents. The trial court allowed him to summon 35 witnesses in all

facts.text: Cases against Kulwant Rai withdrawn on direction from Home Secretary dated May 18, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that two cases against him were withdrawn because a communication dated May 18, 1957, was addressed by the Home Secretary to the Punjab Government to the District Magistrate Amritsar, directing him to withdraw the two cases pending against him.

facts.text: Supreme Court notes misdirection by High Court on standard of proof for good faith.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has clearly misdirected itself. because it has expressly observed that in discharging the onus of providing good faith. it is necessary to remember that the plea of good faith must be proved as strictly as if the complainant were being tried for the offenses imputed to him.
S. 500 07 the Indian Penal Code, and the sentence imposed

holdings.text: The impugned statement published by the appellant is per se defamatory.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 of the Code defines defamation. It is unnecessary to set out the said definition. because it is common ground that the impugned statement published by the appellant is per se defamatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties; definition under s.499 IPC accepted without dispute.

holdings.text: In the present case, the ingredient of public good is satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case. the ingredient of public good is satisfied. and the only question which arose for decision in the court below and which arises before us. is whether the imputation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed finding; publication in response to government challenge concerns public interest.

holdings.text: The onus on an accused person who claims the benefit of an exception is discharged by preponderance of probability, not beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under s. 105 of the Evidence Act, if an accused person claims the benefit of Exceptions, the burden of proving his plea that his case falls under the Exceptions is on the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.105 Evidence Act; precedents like Woolmington, Carr-Briant; shifts burden back to prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: There is another infirmity in the judgment of the High Court, and that arises from the fact that while dealing with the appellants claim for protection under the Ninth Exception, the learned. Judge

holdings.reasoning_summary: First Exception requires truth; Ninth requires good faith; High Court imported truth requirement erroneously.

holdings.text: Good faith under s.52 IPC requires acting with due care and attention; mere belief insufficient without rational basis.

anchor.surface_text: Good faith is defined by s. 52 of the Code. Nothing, says s. 52, is said to be done or believed in good faith which is done or believed without due care and attention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition s.52 IPC; distinguished from General Clauses Act; requires rational basis, precedents from High Courts.

holdings.text: There is no general rule that written statements filed after s.342 CrPC examination should be distrusted as afterthoughts.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge has passed severe strictures against the contents of the written statement and has blamed the appellants lawyer for having advised him to make these contentions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No provision deprecates; s.256 CrPC allows; value depends on facts, delay, consistency with prior actions.

holdings.text: The appellant had not been materially prejudiced by lack of opportunity to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: as regards the grievance made by the appellant that he had not been given a reasonable opportunity to lead his evidence, the High Court held that the said grievance was not well-founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding accepted; examined 20/35 witnesses; documents not useful; no interference under Art.136.

holdings.text: The appellant acted in good faith when he published the impugned statement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-examined evidence due to misdirection; witnesses, documents show rational basis, prior information, due care.

holdings.text: The appellant is entitled to claim the protection of the Ninth Exception to s.499 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: our conclusion is that the appellant is entitled to claim the protection of the Ninth Exception.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Good faith and public good both satisfied; conviction set aside.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberconsideration of public policy calling for similar stringency in the case of an accused person endeavoring to displace a rebuttable presumption. In R.v. Corr-Braint 1 , a somewhat similar question arose before the Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: in case under Prevention of Corruption Act, accused onus to rebut presumption of corruption is by probability, not beyond reasonable doubt
precedents.cited_holding: the onus on the accused was only to satisfy the jury of the probability of that which he was called upon to establish

precedents.citation: the Petition of Shibo Prosad Pandah 1

anchor.surface_text: As has held by the Calcutta High Court in the matter of the Petition of Shibo Prosad Pandah 1 , in dealing with the question of good faith, the proper point to be decided is number whether the allegations put forward by the accused in support of the defamation are in. substance true,

precedents.cited_proposition: in dealing with good faith, proper point is whether accused informed and had good reason after due care and attention to believe allegations true, not whether allegations true

precedents.citation: Emperor v. Abdool Wadood A htned 2

anchor.surface_text: Another aspect of this requirement has been pithily expressed by the Bombay High Court in the case of Emperor v. Abdool Wadood A htned 2 . Good faith, it was observed requires number indeed logical infallibility, but due care and attention.

precedents.cited_proposition: good faith requires due care and attention, not logical infallibility; erroneous statements imputed to want of care depend on circumstances, capacity, intelligence

precedents.citation: Tilkeshwar Singh and others v. The State of Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of his finding that written statements of this kind should be discouraged and cannot be seriously taken into account, the learned Judge had referred to two decisions of this Court. One is the case of Tilkeshwar Singh and others v. The State of Bihar 1 , where this Court was called upon

precedents.case_name: Tilkeshwar Singh v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: s 342 contemplates examination in court, practice of filing written statements deprecated unless prejudice shown

precedents.citation: Sidheswar Ganguly v. State of West BengalC

anchor.surface_text: The other decision the learned Judge has referred to is in the case of Sidheswar Ganguly v. State of West BengalC . In that case, this Court has observed that there is numberprovision in the Code of Criminal Procedure for a written statement of the accused being filed at the Sessions stage,

precedents.case_name: Sidheswar Ganguly v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: no provision for written statement at sessions stage; allowing it in jury trial may introduce irrelevant matter

justification_sets.label: First Exception to IPC Section 499 support

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the evidence to which our attention was drawn by Mr. Bhasin as well as Mr. Anand, and we have come to the conclusion that the High Court was in error in holding that the appellant had failed to show that he acted in good faith when he published the impugned statement. As we have already stated, it has been found by the High Court and it is not disputed before us that the publication of the impugned statement was for the public good and so, our conclusion is that the appellant is entitled to claim the protection of the Ninth Exception.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court erred in holding lack of good faith; appellant entitled to protection of Ninth Exception to s.499 IPC
